## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

```{r}
#using this for data manipulation
library(dplyr)
#using this to tidy up the data
library(tidyverse)
#using for visual data
library(ggplot2)


```


```{r}
# Read CSV file from a subfolder

LITdata <- read_csv("Literacy/Adults_15YrsAndUp.csv")

LIT_rate_data <- read_csv("Literacy/Literacy rates.csv")


LITdata
LIT_rate_data

LIT_rate_data %>% arrange(desc(Year), desc(Country))

```



```{r}
#Literacy rate Country Table
table(LIT_rate_data$Country)


# rate for female in each region
f <- LIT_rate_data %>% 
        filter(Gender == "female") %>% 
        ggplot(aes(x = Region, y = `Literacy rate`))

f + 
  geom_col() + 
  coord_flip() 

# rate for male in each region
m <- LIT_rate_data %>% 
        filter(Gender == "male") %>% 
        ggplot(aes(x = Region, y = `Literacy rate`))

m + 
  geom_col() + 
  coord_flip() 

```

```{r}
p <- ggplot(LIT_rate_data, aes(x = LIT_rate_data$`Year`, y = LIT_rate_data$`Literacy rate`, color = LIT_rate_data$Region)) 
p <- p +  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~ Region)

p
```

```{r}
ggplot(data = LIT_rate_data) + 
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x = Region, fill = Gender))+ coord_flip()

```


```{r}
ggplot(LIT_rate_data %>% filter(Gender == "female"), aes(x = Year, y = `Literacy rate`)) + geom_line() + geom_point()
```
